sub_title: Agroforestry: modelling agro-ecology, economics; extension, project assessment
summary:
Frank's motto is: "everybody can grow trees and earn", and in this end, he developed software to estimate production, cash-flow and environmental of farms and landscapes. With every new assignment, Frank expands his FarmTree® Model, and the team working with it with DIBcoop, that he is co-owning. The emerging Monitoring and Evaluation Protocol is used for a range of applications:
1. Combine Plot Modelling with Geodata, assess the potential impact of Landscape Restoration Projects; and link their quantified performance to Sustainable Development Goals (ICRAF-Ethiopia, EUDel-Rwanda)
2. Quantify the impact of Landscape Restoration by comparing baseline and with-project management scenarios for thousands of farms (ICRAF Tanzania, Kenya, Rwanda, Ethiopia)
2. Based on farmers' testimonies and literature, create a model for Farmer Managed Natural Regeneration, and show that it triples cow carrying capacity on sylvo-pastoral farms (World Vision, Kenya) 
3. Quantify investments and economic returns for irrigation facilities for smallholders' horticulture enterprises; often as part of adaptation projects (World Vision / SNV / Oxfam Kenya, Senegal, Mali, Niger)
4. Quantify social and environmental costs and benefits for farm management scenarios: gender-segregated labour inputs, production per area or per labour input; shade, temperature, soil humidity over seasons, soil fertility over decades, carbon, etc.
5. Provide project-level budgets and returns, such as in 2015 Projects d'Appui à l'Agroforesterie Entrepreneuriale in three West-African countries; in 2014 the Katsina Fuel Wood Balance project of Oxfam
6. Support writing National Agroforestry strategies (EUDel Bhutan)

Keywords in Frank's experience include:
*Agroforestry, Smallholders, Diversity, Sustainable Development Goals, Smart Water, Modelling, Financial analysis, Climate Adaptation and Mitigation, Entrepreneurship, Gender-in-development, Action Research, Documentation; linking theory and practice
*Providing conditions for investments: Investment & Returns analysis, Cash Flow Planning, Economic Indicators, Risk Assessment; Design, Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning in landscape restoration programmes

projects.description: Peter Paap and I have been tinkering with the idea that Agroforestry is not only an activity for subsistence or environental purpose, but equally an economic activity. Taking trees as an economic component of Agroforestry systems we conceptualised business planning with the FarmTree(r) Tool that calculates economic benefits of crops (short term), animals (medium term) and trees (long term).

profile_positions.description: DIBcoop acquired Frank's FarmTree® Model to serve landscape managers and farmers in projecting costs and benefits of Agroforestry options. This enriches DIBcoop's smallholder entreprise promotion projects, GIS expertise, and FarmTree's range of Model application. The new team is working with partners to capture their landscape work's impact in terms of Sustainable Development Goal indicators. Frank guides the team to develop the Model; and, jointly with clients, both applies and elaborates FarmTree® across the globe.
profile_positions.title: Consultant and FarmTree® Model developer

profile_positions.description:
*Designing and guiding Agroforestry/Horticulture Development Programmes in West-Africa (Senegal, Niger, Mali, with options in Nigeria, Burkina, etc.) 
*Designing and testing FarmTree® Software for forecasting Agroforestry plot economic balances over 1-15 years, and developing economic investment models for each rural group: women, smallholder farmers, landless, youth, pastoralists. 
*Accompanying Government institutions taking the lead in sector reform - e.g., on land governance (Mozambique) or forestry sector reform (Terai, Nepal) 
*Exploring opportunities around farming with trees in the Climate Change context: the Carbon Market, REDD+ and adaptation funding
*Decentralised local governments are key to coordinate local actors such as farmers organisations, business, development projects, etc.

Thus key words in my profile are: Agriculture, Forestry, Agroforestry systems, Financial Services, Entrepreneurship, Scaling-up; men, women, youth, pastoralists, smallholders; Governance; Livelihood, Food security; Africa, Sahel, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Mozambique, Tunisia; Asia, Nepal, India, Bhutan, Indonesia

profile_positions.description: My responsibilities include overseeing the development of an Agroforestry-Based Entrepreneurship Programme where I play a pivotal role with Partners for Innovation colleagues in West-Africa. In 2015 we implemented three Projects for Support to Entrepreneurial Agroforestry in Senegal, Mali and Niger. I developed an Economic Balance calculation tool for 15-year economic planning of Agroforestry plots (the FarmTree(r) Tool) that now is used for routinely developing business plans for smallholder farmers and farmers' groups. This allows for adaptation to climate change and rural employment generation. In November alone we developed 20 business plans for in total some 25 ha of Agroforestry planning.

profile_positions.description: Reform of the Terai Forestry Sector: With dedicated Government Officials, I developed a participatory Governance mechanisms for Terai Forestry, i.e., Collaborative Forest Management (involving a few million people in block forest management) and District Forestry Coordination Committees. About two million ha of subtropical forest needed co-operation between Government, Civil Society and Private Sector. We developed a multi-actor legal framework and financial flow system, that allowed for participation of people on the ground.

profile_positions.description: Developing a plant protection service in the remoter parts of eastern Bhutan - focussing on a fruitfly in Citrus. The work resulted in a PhD on the relation between technical innovation and social reform at community level - so-called "socio-technical innovations". This theses stood at the basis of a programme developed at Wageningen University called "Convergence of Sciences".
